keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, increasing vulnerability—especially in developing nations.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress has been observed in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and issuing standardized alerts.
Early warning systems enable early action, which is critical to saving lives and protecting infrastructure.
The WMO calls for global action to close monitoring and forecasting gaps due to the spiraling impact of extreme weather linked to climate change.
A key real-world example is the evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten in May 2025, after scientists warned of a glacier collapse due to permafrost melt.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), under the United Nations, has released a report warning that nearly half of the world's countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leading to disproportionately high death tolls—especially in developing nations. Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate hazards in the past 50 years, with 90% of those deaths occurring in developing countries. While the number of countries using some form of early-warning systems has increased from 52 to 108, half still have only basic capacity, and 16% have less than basic capacity. The situation is most severe in fragile and conflict-affected regions. Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries launching standardized alerts. The WMO emphasizes that early warning systems enable early action, saving lives and protecting infrastructure. Real-world examples, such as the evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, after a glacier collapse predicted in May 2025 due to permafrost melt, underscore the urgency and effectiveness of timely monitoring and alerts.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
